entry.title: How inpeek Leveraged the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine to Power a Chatbot for Structured Data
entry.content:
At inpeek , we are always looking for innovative ways to make our solutions smarter and more efficient. Our SaaS product Summarix supports us in managing CVs, project references, skills, customers, and more, enabling the seamless creation of call-for-tender documents. To make the work of our employees and sales team easier, we set out to simplify how users interact with Summarix‚Äôs structured data. Out of this ambition, Summy, our AI-powered chatbot, was born. 

We realized this project in close collaboration with SAP through the Early Adopter Care (EAC) Program for the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine, a powerful extension of the SAP HANA database. In the following sections, we will share details of the Summy project, the challenges we encountered, and the technical decisions that shaped the solution. 

The Challenge 

Summarix already provided a user-friendly UI with filtering and search capabilities built on SAP Fiori, SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) and deployed on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) . While this approach worked well for simple questions, it did have several limitations:  

  • Filters could only cover what the product owners or developers had envisioned. 
  • Complex questions across multiple entities quickly exceeded the UI‚Äôs filter options. 
  • Aggregational queries (e.g., identifying the most experienced consultant in a skill or calculating the average years of experience over all consultants) were impossible with standard filters. 

In order to overcome these challenges and accelerate the search process, we envisioned a chatbot that would be capable of: 

  • Focus on information retrieval from structured data. 
  • Provide precise, single-turn answers to questions. 
  • Leverage new SAP technologies, particularly the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine. 

This was also an opportunity for us to gain early hands-on experience with the Knowledge Graph Engine and to explore its potential.  

The Solution 

We implemented an innovative architecture built entirely on the SAP BTP. The system combines a knowledge graph and an agentic workflows to deliver precise answers to questions regarding the data stored in Summarix. 

‚ÄÉ

Key components of the solution: 

  • SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine: Stores data as a knowledge graph, facilitating SPARQL-based queries. 
  • SAP CAP backend: Manages orchestration, workflow logic, and query processing. While Python is a popular choice for many AI projects , we deliberately chose to integrate AI into our CAP (Node.js) backend using the SAP AI SDK. Utilising LangGraph.js and LangChain.js, we have modeled the agentic workflow directly in JavaScript. 
  • SAP Generative AI Hu: Provides access to LLM inference. We leverage its orchestration features and prompt templates, while retaining the flexibility to switch between models from OpenAI, Amazon, Google... 
  • Angular UI: A lightweight chat interface that runs as a shell plugin within the SAP Work Zone. 
  • Langfuse: Ensures observability and evaluation. This open-source tool enables us to trace executions, measure performance, and curate evaluation datasets. 

Key Features 

Our chatbot relies on an agentic AI workflow. While it is not a fully autonomous agent, the workflow defines a repeatable sequence of steps with conditional branches. This approach ensures consistency, reduces risks, and simplifies debugging, while still supporting dynamic, question-specific workflows and granting the agent some autonomy. 

Knowledge Graph Generation 

The project started with building the knowledge graph, which is based on the structured data from the SAP HANA Database of Summarix. This includes the following steps: 

  1. Export data from SQL into CSV. 
  1. Create graph nodes for entities (e.g., employees, projects, skills) with attributes while omitting irrelevant columns. 
  1. Model n-n relationships through connection nodes. 
  1. Export everything into Turtle (.ttl) files. 
  1. Ingest these files into the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine. 

Ensuring data quality is paramount, as errors in this area can propagate through to the chatbot and significantly impact downstream task performance. As part of the ongoing development and implementation of improvements, the knowledge graph creation process has been repeatedly revised and enhanced . 

Entity Extraction and Matching 

Users naturally phrase questions in different ways (e.g., SAP BTP vs. SAP Business Technology Platform). Since each skill has a canonical name in Summarix, robust entity matching is required. 

Our approach, involved the following steps: 

  • Extract potential entities (skills, employees, projects and customers) from the question via an LLM using few-shot learning. 
  • Normalize entity names (singular form, multiple known variations). 
  • Search with regex-based case-insensitive filters for the existing entities. 

After matching the entities, we store them in the agent state for subsequent steps. 

SPARQL Query Generation 

After identifying the entities , the next step is to generate a SPARQL query. To guide the LLM, we did a lot of context engineering and provide: 

  • Context such as identity, instructions, and current date/time. 
  • The full ontology of the knowledge graph, including attributes and relationships. 
  • Detailed descriptions of all attributes, entities and relations. 
  • Examples of valid SPARQL queries. 

For this step, we (currently) rely on GPT-4.1 for its stronger reasoning capabilities, while lighter calls use GPT-4o-mini. 

We chose to use a knowledge graph approach, although it would also be possible to directly generate SQL and execute queries against the relational SAP HANA Cloud database. In our experiments, answers based on SQL queries showed slightly lower performance compared to those derived from the knowledge graph approach. 

Evaluation and Observability 

From day one,, we prioritized evaluation at inpeek to avoid a ‚Äúblack-box‚Äù development process and to establish clear KPIs and track their development over time. The key steps of our evaluation include: 

  • Curated a baseline dataset (~30 items) with questions and ground truth answers. 
  • Built an evaluation API endpoint to automatically rerun the dataset after each iteration. 
  • Use LLM-as-a-judge scoring (0‚Äì1) to assess the correctness of an answer compared to the ground truth answer. 
  • Introduced user feedback loops: flagged chatbot answers are added to new datasets, enabling continuous improvement based on previous incorrect answers. 
  • Track additional metrics, such as latency, costs and self-correction steps. 

Key Technical Considerations 

  • Multi-tenancy: Since Summarix is a SaaS product, we implemented our own multi-tenant logic to support different environments. So far , the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph does not offer multi-tenancy capabilites.  
  • Automated KG ingestion: A tenant-aware Python job daily updates the knowledge graph as data evolves in Summarix. 
  • CAP instead of Python: By keeping everything in CAP (Node.js), we simplified integration with authentication, lifecycle management, and SAP tooling. 
  • Context engineering: Providing a complete ontology with extended descriptions is crucial for reliable SPARQL generation. 
  • Evaluation-first approach: Systematic evaluation ensured objective improvements and prevented regressions.

Conclusion 

With Summy, we explored how the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine can serve as a foundation for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) on structured data. By combining knowledge graphs, SPARQL, LLMs and agentic workflows, we created a chatbot that can provide precise answers to complex business questions. This means consultants and sales reps can now answer tender-related questions in seconds instead of manually filtering data! 

This project demonstrated that success hinges on more than just the agent workflow, it also depends on data quality, entity mapping and evaluation pipelines. We had an excellent experience with the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine and look forward to building on this foundation for future use cases. 

There is also a Medium blog post that delves deeper into the AI Engineering aspect, as well as a SAP Success Story highlighting the use of the knowledge graph for the chatbot and our SaaS solution, Summarix

If you‚Äôd like to learn more about this project or discuss AI in the SAP ecosystem, feel free to conntact us on LinkedIn: 

Fabian H√ºni (AI Engineer)
Fabian K√ºng (SAP Expert Consultant)

entry.title: New Machine Learning, NLP and AI features in SAP HANA Cloud 2025 Q4
entry.content:
With the SAP HANA Cloud 2025 Q4 release, several new embedded Machine Learning / AI functions  have been released with the with the Predictive Analysis Library (PAL), the Automated Predictive Library (APL) and the NLP Services in SAP HANA Cloud.

Key new capabilities to be highlighted include

  • A new unified time series procedure, serving developers to utilize the same interface across different times series algorithms
  • text embedding model enhancements, supporting output vector dimensionality reduction, while maintaining retrieval accuracy
  • a new cross encoder model with the NLP services, for accurately re-ranking search results
  • text column input, text embedding operators with AutoML classification and regression models
  • text tokenization enhancements supporting regular expression token filtering and a new text log parsing function for detecting and determining new log pattern
  • the HANA ML experiment monitor UI now supports visual model monitoring and drift analysis

An enhancement summary is available in the What‚Äôs new document for SAP HANA Cloud database 2025.40 (QRC 4/2025).

 

Time series enhancements

Introducing Unified Time Series interfaces

Unified time series is a newly introduced interface for a simplified use of multiple time series algorithms (ARIMA, Exponential Smoothing, Bayesian Structural Time Series (BSTS) and Additive Model Analysis (aka prophet)).

  • it allows for application developers to flexibly consume different time series analysis algorithms using the same procedure interface and a harmonized the handling of time series data patterns, avoiding algorithm-specific data preparation.
  • It also supports massive, data-parallel time series modeling for maximum parallelism and performance when modeling thousands of time series in parallel

 

A more detailed introduction to the new function is given in the following blog post https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/simplifying-time-series-analytics-with-unified-time-series-interface/ba-p/14292218

 

AutoML time series now support Prediction Intervals

AutoML time series predict function, in addition to all regular time series functions, now supports prediction intervals for probabilistic forecasting

  • the uncertainty associated with a forecast is quantified by providing a range (lower/upper bounds) into which a future observation likely falls with a specific confidence level.
  • For example a 95% prediction interval contains the true value 95% of the time

 

Text embedding model enhancements (NLP services)

Output vector dimension reduction

The Text Embedding models in SAP HANA Cloud have been enhanced with an attached a linear layer‚Äã‚Äã, derived from PCA trainings, to allow for the output vector dimensionality reduction

  • The arget dimension cardinality can be flexibly set to 128, 256 384, 512, 768 dimensions using ‚Äã‚ÄãPCA_DIM_NUM parameter
  • A near-original retrieval task accuracy is sustained with 256 dimensions, at 1/3rd of the original vector size (768 dimensions)
  • While lower dimension values than 128 would lead to significant and critical-level accuracy loss for retrieval tasks, hence 256 dimensions‚Äã‚Äã is recommended for efficiency & performance

Now text embeddings of significantly lower dimensionality can be utilized at a minimal information loss for retrieval tasks as well as machine learning.

Moreover smaller vector sizes unlock much faster machine learning processing times and may also serve vector retrieval queries

 

Text feature data support with AutoML models

Text column data and Text Embedding Operator in AutoML models

With the introduction of the a new text embedding operator for AutoML models, text columns can be directly used as input feature data and benefit from automatic, and optimized text vectorization utilizing SAP HANA Clouds text embedding models.

  • Text columns can be processed as feature, specified with the new parameter TEXT_VARIABLE
  • In addition, the new TextEmbedding operator supports the new target dimension reduction with the parameter PCA_DIM_NUM 
  • The enhancement are available with the SQL interface as well as hana-ml 2.27 in Python

With that, the semantic insights from text columns can get automatically unlocked when building AutoML classification / regression models.

 

Cross Encoder Model (NLP services)

Accurate re-ranking of search results

The family NLP services in SAP HANA Cloud has now been enriched with a new cross encoder model and respective PAL functions. The cross encoder model

  • Processes pairs/sets of text sentences (query, candidate results) together
  • Therefore allows for a more precise semantic similarity re-ranking of search results, based on the full contextual interaction analysis between the query and the input candidate set (e.g. a an initial result set retrieved from a vector engine similarity search)
  • Thus much higher accurate and relevant-ranked similarity search results can be achieved

 

Moreover the use of cross encoder models allows to combine multiple result sets retrieved from for example classic text search and vector engine similarity search queries into a hybrid search result, which can be passed into the cross encoder for its overall and combined re-ranking.

Custom AI, Retrieval Augmented Generation Applications (RAG) can now fully be served by Text Embedding Models, Vector Engine with Similarity Search and the Cross Encoder model, managing context privacy from the SAP HANA Cloud database.

 

Text tokenization enhancements and new automated log text analysis

Text tokenization support for regular expressions

The text pre-processing function Text Tokenize function for splitting input text into smaller units called tokens, has now been enhanced and supports regular expression for filtering token output patterns.

  • Custom filtering (removal/keeping) of text patterns can be applied
  • List of regular expressions, matching tokens will be kept / excluded
  • Typical filtering examples include extracting e-mail addresses, URLs, or other token patterns for domain-specific needs

 

Automatic pattern detection from log texts

A new analysis function for log text documents Text Log Parse has been added to the Predictive Analysis Library, which allows

  • For an automatic extraction of new log patterns and derive templates for new log patterns
  • High-performant processing of log texts for log classification and automated log analysis, the ability to detect and alert for new log patterns

 

 

ML experiment tracking and task scheduling enhancements

Experiment tracking enhancements

Tracking of experiments, now supports custom track entity tags

  • Standard track entities generated in PAL Training, Forecast, etc. can now be enriched with custom tags like business related information associated with related track entity
  • Tag is name-value pair for annotation or note, binding extra information to existing entities

 

A more detailed introduction is provided in the following blog post comprehensive-guide-to-mltrack-in-sap-hana-cloud-end-to-end-machine 

Moreover the Experiment Monitor in the Python Machine Learning client (hana-ml) supports for visually monitoring ML model performance degradation and drift.

 

One-off scheduling of PAL tasks

The PAL procedure scheduling interfaces has been enhance with a One-OFF schedule option, allowing for

  • ad-hoc, automatic one-off scheduled execution of PAL task procedures with dynamic setting of time-frequency information based on current UTC timestamp
  • it triggers a scheduled job to execute immediately, and the corresponding one-off schedule is removed right away and doesn‚Äôt require to be manually maintained.

 

Python ML client (hana-ml) enhancements

The full list of new methods and enhancements with hana_ml 2.27  is summarized in the changelog for hana-ml 2.27 as part of the documentation.  You can find an examples notebook illustrating the highlighted feature enhancements here 25QRC04_2.27.ipynb.

The key enhancements in this release include the following: 

Time series data outlier detection with threshold support

The method for time series outlier detection in the Predictive Analysis Library has added support outlier threshold settings, in addition to the outlier voting capability using different outlier evaluation methods incl.  Z1 score, Z2 score, IIQR score, MAD score, IsolationForest and DBSCAN

  • If the absolute value of outlier score is beyond the threshold, the respective data point will be considered as an outlier.

Time series reports for massive, data-parallel model scenarios

Massive AutoML Time Series modeling scenarios often utilize random-search with hyperband as the fastest optimization, potentially with larger number of time series data segment groups to be processed and forecasted in parallel, each time series segment group again with a significant number of forecast models to be explored. 

Hence the display of forecasts which have been explored by AutoML within each time series segment group is collapsed by default and can be expanded for review.

 

 

Classification and regression function enhancements

Support Vector Machine (SVM) model training is computationally expensive, and computational costs are specifically sensitive to the number of training points, which makes SVM models often impractical for large datasets.

The SVM algorithm now supports Coreset Sampling

  • which allows to automatically sample small, representative subsets (the "coreset") from larger datasets,
  • enabling faster, more efficient training and processing while maintaining similar model accuracy as using the full data.

This enhancement significantly reduces SVM training time with minimal impact on accuracy.

 

The model report for classification tasks now supports a percentage display in confusion matrix for easier visual interpretation of classification results.

 

High-dimensional feature data reduction using UMAP

UMAP (Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection) is a non-linear dimensionality reduction algorithm used to simplify complex, high-dimensional feature spaces, while preserving its essential structure. It is widely considered the modern gold standard for visualizing targeted dimension reduction of large-scale datasets, because it balances computational speed with the ability to maintain both local and global relationships.

  • It reduces thousands of variables (dimensions) into 2D or 3D scatter plots that humans can easily interpret.
  • Unlike comparable methods like t-SNE, UMAP is better at preserving global structure, meaning the relative positions between different clusters remain more meaningful.
  • It is significantly faster and more memory-efficient than t-SNE, capable of processing datasets with millions of points in a reasonable timeframe.
  • It can be used as a "transformer" preprocessing step in Machine Learning scenarios to reduce large feature spaces before applying clustering (e.g., k-means, HDBSCAN) or classification models, often improving their performance.

 

Calculating pairwise distances

Many algorithms, for example clustering algorithms utilize distance matrixes as a preprocessing step, often inbuild the functions. Often there is the wish to decouple though the distance matrix calculation from the follow-up task like the actual clustering. Moreover, if decoupled custom calculated matrixes can be fed into algorithms as input.

  • Most PAL clustering functions support to feed-in a pre-calculated similarity matrix

Now, a pairwise distance calculation function is provided

  • It supports distance metrics like Manhattan, Euclidien, Minkowski, Chebyshey as well as Levenshtein
  • The Levenshtein distance (or edit distance) is a distance metric specifically targeting distance between text-columns. It calculates the minimum number of single-character edits (insertions, deletions, or substitutions) needed to transform one word into another, acting as a measure of their similarity. A lower distance indicates a higher similarity.

Applicable use cases

  • It is useful in data cleaning, table column similarity analysis between columns of the same data type.
  • After calculating the column similarity across all data types, clustering like K-Means can be applied to group similar fields and propose mappings for fields within the same cluster

 

Again, an incredible set of enhancements in the SAP HANA Cloud database AI engine and NLP services!

Enjoy to try out all the enhancements and let us know what you think here!

entry.title: Did you know SAP BTP Destination Fragments and how to consume to integrate ?
entry.content:
In the era of hyper-automation and low-code/no-code platforms, seamless connectivity between services is critical. SAP BTP‚Äôs Destination Fragments provide a standardized, reusable approach to managing API endpoints, security configurations, and network policies.

This blog explores how developers can consume Destination Fragments in SAP Build Apps, Process Automation, and other development contexts to accelerate integration, enhance security, and streamline governance.

Reference : SAP Help Documentation - Destinations with Fragments

1. What Are Destination Fragments?

Destination Fragments are reusable configuration components in SAP BTP that define:

  • Target endpoints (e.g., SAP S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors, or external APIs).
  • Authentication methods (OAuth, Basic Auth, Client Certificates).
  • Network policies (e.g., CORS, whitelisting).
  • Custom headers or query parameters.

Fragments are consumed by Destinations, which act as unified gateways for applications to access backend systems securely.

2. Why Consume Destination Fragments?

  • Reusability: Define once, use across multiple applications.
  • Security Centralization: Enforce consistent authentication and encryption.
  • Governance: Ensure compliance with enterprise policies.
  • Simplicity: Eliminate manual configuration for each service.

3. How to Consume Destination Fragments

Follow these steps to consume a Destination Fragment in your BTP subaccount:

Step 1: Create a Destination

  1. Navigate to SAP BTP Cockpit > Connectivity > Destinations .
  2. Define properties:
    • Name: my-fragment.
    • Type: HTTP.
    • URL: https://api.example.com.
    • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials.
    • Client ID/Secret: Stored in BTP secrets.

Step 2: Create a Destination Using the Fragment

  1. you will have to perform API request to create a New Fragment as there is no option of creation via UI in BTP - Destination 

Step 3: Consume in Applications

Applications access the destination via the destination service:

// Example: Resolve a destination with an optional fragment and call its target URL.
// Requires: axios ^1.x

const axios = require('axios');

async function callViaDestination() {
  // Replace with your values
  const region = 'eu10'; // e.g., eu10, us10, etc.
  const destinationName = 'AVR'; // your destination name
  const fragmentName = 'APIKey'; // optional: the name of the destination fragment to apply
  const accessToken = process.env.DEST_CONF_ACCESS_TOKEN; // bearer token for Destination Configuration service

  const baseUrl = `https://destination-configuration.cfapps.${region}.hana.ondemand.com`;
  const destUrl = `${baseUrl}/destination-configuration/v1/destinations/${encodeURIComponent(destinationName)}`;

  try {
    // 1) Resolve destination (apply fragment via header if provided)
    const headers = {
      'Authorization': `Bearer ${accessToken}`,
      'Accept': 'application/json',
    };
    if (fragmentName) {
      headers['X-Fragment-Name'] = fragmentName; // apply fragment
    }

    const { data: destination } = await axios.get(destUrl, { headers });

    // destination typically includes properties like URL, headers, and possibly Authorization
    // depending on the auth type configured in the destination.
    const targetUrl = destination.URL;
    const targetHeaders = { ...(destination.headers || {}) };

    // If the resolved destination returns an Authorization header (e.g., OAuth flow handled by Destination service),
    // propagate it to the call below.
    if (destination.Authorization) {
      targetHeaders['Authorization'] = destination.Authorization;
    }

    // 2) Call the resolved target URL (GET as example)
    const response = await axios.get(targetUrl, {
      headers: targetHeaders,
      // If your destination requires additional headers like sap-client etc.,
      // they may be present in destination.properties or destination.headers.
      // You can map them into targetHeaders as needed.
    });

    console.log('Status:', response.status);
    console.log('Data:', response.data);
  } catch (err) {
    // Helpful diagnostics
    if (err.response) {
      console.error('Destination/Target call failed:', err.response.status, err.response.data);
    } else {
      console.error('Error:', err.message);
    }
  }
}

callViaDestination();

4. Use Cases & Diagrams

Use Case 1: SAP Build Apps (Low-Code)

Scenario: A Build App needs to fetch data from SAP S/4HANA Sales Orders.

  • Fragment: Preconfigured with OAuth2ClientCredentials and S/4HANA endpoint.
  • Consumption: Drag-and-drop the destination into the app‚Äôs data source.

Diagram:

Use Case 2: SAP Process Automation

Scenario: A workflow triggers an external payment gateway API.

  • Fragment: Includes API URL, Basic Auth, and retry policies.
  • Consumption: Use the destination name in a REST API step.

Diagram:

Use Case 3: CAP-Based Applications

Scenario: A CAP service reads data from a custom API.

  • Fragment: Configured with JWT Bearer token and CORS settings.
  • Consumption: Reference the destination in cds.env.

Diagram:

5. Key Benefits

  • Accelerated Development: Reduce integration time by 40%+ using pre-configured fragments.
  • Consistent Security: Enforce MFA, encryption, and auditing across all apps.
  • Centralized Control: Update endpoints/authentications once; changes propagate everywhere.
  • Compliance: Align with ISO 27001, GDPR, and enterprise security policies.

6. Conclusion

Destination Fragments in SAP BTP are a game-changer for developers, enabling secure, reusable, and governance-ready integrations. Whether you‚Äôre building low-code apps, automating processes, or developing enterprise services, fragments simplify connectivity while maintaining security and compliance.

Next Steps:

  • Explore the SAP BTP Destination Documentation.
  • Try fragments in the SAP BTP Destination Fragment API Doc.

By leveraging Destination Fragments, you future-proof your integrations and focus on innovation‚Äînot configuration chaos.

entry.title: Securing SAP Business AI Architectures: Trust Boundaries and Secure Data Flows
entry.content:
(Jana Subramanian serves as Head of Cybersecurity and Compliance for SEA and is a Fellow of Information Privacy (FIP), awarded by the International Association of Privacy Professionals (IAPP). In this role, Jana supports strategic customer engagements on cybersecurity, data privacy, multi-cloud security integration architecture, contractual assurance, audit, and compliance.)

Introduction

AI is no longer an isolated innovation experiment in enterprises. It is becoming deeply embedded in core business processes. In the SAP ecosystem, this evolution has created a rich but multi-layered landscape: embedded machine learning in applications, side-by-side AI on SAP BTP,  generative AI via SAP Generative AI Hub and Joule as an AI copilot. A common question from customers, architects, and privacy professionals alike is: ‚ÄúWhat architectural models sit behind SAP Business AI use cases, and what are the trust boundaries for my data and the security of data flows in SAP Business AI?‚Äù

This blog answers that question by explaining SAP Business AI through clear architecture patterns. Each pattern is designed for different business needs, risk levels, and degrees of customization. Instead of individual products, we focus on how data flows, where intelligence runs, how access is controlled, and how compliance is maintained. This blog is intended for conceptual understanding, not detailed configuration guidance.

Embedded AI

The Embedded AI architecture pattern represents SAP‚Äôs approach to executing machine learning directly within the cloud applications system boundary such as S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors or other cloud applications. In this model, intelligence is built into the digital core itself rather than being consumed from external AI services.

When a user action or business process triggers a prediction request, the ABAP application layer does not transmit data outside the system. Instead, it invokes Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM), which determines the appropriate machine learning scenario, model version, and execution logic. ISLM then orchestrates execution within the SAP HANA database, where algorithms from the Predictive Analysis Library (PAL) or Automated Predictive Library (APL) run in-memory, directly alongside the transactional data.

Once the prediction is computed, the result flows back through ISLM to the ABAP layer and is immediately consumed by the business process. At no point does enterprise data leave the S/4HANA trust boundary.

The critical advantage of this pattern is zero data movement. Sensitive business data remains entirely within the S/4HANA system, making Embedded AI the strongest posture for strict data-minimization / no-egress requirements and deterministic option for transaction-specific, real-time predictions such as credit risk scoring, demand forecasting, delivery date prediction, or invoice blocking decisions.

Secure Data Flow

  1. User/Process triggers a prediction in the business process.
  2. ABAP application layer initiates the ML call (often via DB-proximate execution).
  3. ISLM orchestration / scenario management selects the scenario/model.
  4. HANA executes PAL/APL algorithms next to the business data (in-memory).
  5. Prediction result returns to the business process.

Aspect

How Embedded AI Addresses It

Data Residency

All processing occurs within the customer‚Äôs S/4HANA instance. Data never crosses network boundaries or leaves the system landscape, supporting strict data sovereignty and localization requirements (for example, GDPR and regional regulations).

Access Control

Embedded AI leverages existing SAP authorization concepts (roles, profiles, authorization objects). Users can only access predictions for business objects they are already authorized to view or process‚Äîno separate IAM layer is required.

Audit Trail

ISLM maintains comprehensive logs covering model training, deployment, and inference execution. These integrate with SAP‚Äôs standard logging and audit mechanisms (for example, application logs and system logs) to support compliance and audit reporting.

Data Encryption

Data protection relies on SAP HANA‚Äôs native encryption mechanisms for data at rest and in transit. No additional encryption layers are required, as data does not leave the internal system boundary.

Model Governance

ISLM enforces model lifecycle governance, including version control, approval workflows, and transport management. ML models follow the same change and release controls as ABAP code, ensuring consistent governance.

Third-Party Exposure

Unlike side-by-side AI or external LLM patterns, no data is transmitted to third-party AI providers. This eliminates external vendor trust dependencies and reduces the need for additional data processing agreements.

 

Side-by-side AI inference on SAP BTP using SAP AI Core

 This pattern keeps the digital core clean by running AI inference side-by-side on SAP BTP. A user interacts with a Fiori app, the request is handled by a BTP application (CAP/Node.js), and inference is executed in SAP AI Core inside a managed runtime (Docker container). The important security idea is that the user does not call the model directly. The BTP application is the controlled middleware that enforces authentication, authorization, and data minimization before sending anything for inference.

  1. Request Initiation: A user interacts with an SAP Fiori Application, which triggers an inference request (e.g., a text prompt or data for classification).
  2. CAP Middleware Layer: The request is sent to a Cloud Application Programming (CAP) model or Node.js service. This layer acts as the orchestrator and security gatekeeper.
  3. Authentication: The CAP service uses an OAuth2 Client Credentials flow, facilitated by an SAP AI Core Service Key, to exchange credentials for a secure JSON Web Token (JWT) via SAP‚Äôs XSUAA service.
  4. Inference Execution: The authenticated request is passed to SAP AI Core, which routes it to a specific Docker Container where the AI model is served.
  5. Response Handling: The model processes the input, generates a Response Payload, and sends it back through the CAP service to be rendered in the Fiori UI.

Step #

Flow Component

Security & Privacy Mechanism

Validation & Purpose (corrected)

1

Fiori App ‚Üí CAP

User SSO via IdP/IAS; API protected via OAuth/JWT (often XSUAA); app RBAC

Request accepted only for authenticated users; app validates token and enforces role-based access.

2

CAP ‚Üí AI Core

Service-to-service OAuth using service credentials (service key/binding); TLS; least privilege

CAP calls AI Core securely without hardcoding secrets in code; access scoped to required AI Core resources.

3

AI Core Runtime

Isolated container runtime (Docker); tenant/resource isolation; hardened images/secrets mgmt (recommended)

BYOM/model executes in a controlled AI Core runtime in the region where the service is provisioned (per availability).

4

Data Retrieval (RAG)

HANA Cloud Vector Engine; authorization-aware access; encryption at rest/in transit

Context retrieved from tenant-controlled vector store; embeddings can be stored in-region to support residency requirements.

5

Response Payload

Internal return path via BTP app; response validation; optional output filtering/redaction

Response returned to user through the CAP app. External calls happen only if architecture routes to external providers.

Secure Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) with SAP Business AI:

Flow A represents the controlled ingestion and preparation phase where enterprise content is transformed into vector embeddings and securely stored for later retrieval. This phase is typically offline or asynchronous, which allows stronger governance and validation before any user interaction occurs.

Flow A ‚Äì Ingestion (Preparation)

  1. A1 ‚Äì Ingestion: Enterprise content is securely ingested from authorized SAP or customer-controlled sources using authenticated service access.
  2. A2 ‚Äì Chunking: Content is split into smaller semantic segments to minimize data exposure and improve controlled retrieval.
  3. A3 ‚Äì Embedding: Each chunk is converted into a vector via SAP-governed embedding models with ephemeral processing and no model training.
  4. A4 ‚Äì Vector Storage: Generated embeddings are encrypted and stored in SAP HANA Cloud with tenant isolation and access control.

Flow B represents the runtime path, where a user question is answered using retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). The defining principle here is that context is retrieved first, validated, and only then sent to the LLM.

Flow B ‚Äì Retrieval & Generation

  1. B1 ‚Äì User Question: The user submits a query through an SAP application with identity and authorization already enforced.
  2. B2 ‚Äì Query Embedding: The user query is transformed into a vector using the same secured embedding model for consistent matching.
  3. B3 ‚Äì Vector Search: SAP HANA Cloud performs an authorization-aware similarity search to retrieve the top-K relevant vectors.
  4. B4 ‚Äì Context Selection: Only the most relevant and permitted data chunks are selected as grounding context.
  5. B5 ‚Äì LLM Invocation: The grounded context is sent via SAP GenAI Hub to generate a response with policy and safety guardrails applied.
  6. B6 ‚Äì User Response: A grounded, auditable answer is returned to the user without persisting enterprise data in the LLM.

 

Layer / Step

Security Controls

Privacy Controls

Data Protection & Compliance

Ingestion & Chunking (A1‚ÄìA2)

OAuth-based service authentication, technical users, controlled pipelines

Data minimization, segmentation, metadata classification

Customer-controlled sources, audit logging, least-privilege access

Embedding Generation (A3, B2)

SAP GenAI Hub as policy enforcement point, secure API calls

Ephemeral processing, no training on customer data

Contractual AI usage terms, Responsible AI principles

Vector Storage (A4)

Encryption at rest, tenant isolation, SAP HANA Cloud Security

Store vectors and (if required) chunk text/references under the same tenant isolation + access control

Data residency, SOC 2 / ISO controls

Vector Search (B3)

Authorization-aware retrieval, role-based filtering

Context limited to top-K results

Prevents over-exposure of enterprise data

LLM Invocation (B5)

Guardrails, prompt control, data masking, input filtering output filtering

Context scoped per request, no retention

Hallucination reduction, compliant AI usage

User Response (B6)

End-to-end traceability, secure UI delivery

No unnecessary data disclosure

Auditability and explainability

Orchestration Services in Gen AI Hub on SAP BTP

SAP Gen AI Hub on SAP BTP acts as the central orchestration and governance layer for generative AI, providing standardized and secure access to a broad range of Large Language Models (LLMs), including models hosted on SAP-managed infrastructure as well as selected third-party providers (such as Azure OpenAI, AWS, or Google), depending on the use case and region. Instead of exposing applications directly to LLMs, the GenAI Hub enforces a controlled, policy-driven interaction model.

The core flow for a secure user request includes:

  1. Prompt Templating: User prompts are normalized into approved templates with placeholders, ensuring consistency, reuse, and protection against prompt injection.
  2. Data Masking (Anonymization): Sensitive data, including personally identifiable information (PII), is dynamically masked or pseudonymized before the request is sent to the LLM.
  3. Content Filtering: Input and output filters inspect prompts and responses for unsafe, biased, or non-compliant content in line with SAP Responsible AI principles.
  4. Data Re-identification: After a safe response is returned, previously masked data may be selectively re-identified to restore business context for the end user, subject to policy controls.

This orchestration layer ensures customer data is minimized, protected, and never persistently stored or used for model training by external LLMs.

SAP AI Core: Execution & Lifecycle Management

While the GenAI Hub governs interaction and policy enforcement, SAP AI Core provides the standardized runtime for executing AI workloads on SAP Business Technology Platform. Key capabilities include:

  1. Model Serving: Machine learning models are deployed as scalable, secure inference services with managed lifecycle operations.
  2. Container-Based Execution: Custom AI workloads are packaged and deployed using Docker containers, enabling Bring Your Own Model (BYOM) scenarios with frameworks such as PyTorch or TensorFlow.
  3. Tenant Isolation: AI Core enforces strict isolation between tenants, ensuring that models, data, and execution environments remain segregated across customers.
  4. SAP AI Core ensures operational consistency, scalability, and security across both SAP-delivered and customer-developed AI use cases.

SAP HANA Cloud Vector Engine: Grounding with Business Context

A key risk of generative AI is hallucination‚Äîresponses that are fluent but not factually grounded. SAP addresses this using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG). SAP HANA Cloud provides native vector capabilities that enable secure grounding of LLM responses in enterprise data:

  1. Embeddings & Similarity Search: Unstructured content (such as documents, policies, or contracts) is converted into vector embeddings and stored in the HANA Cloud Vector Engine.
  2. Grounded Retrieval: When a user prompt is processed, a similarity search retrieves the most relevant business context, which is injected into the LLM prompt‚Äîensuring the generated response is based on authoritative, company-specific data. This approach significantly reduces hallucination risk while keeping enterprise data within SAP‚Äôs controlled data boundary.

The Centralized Control Plane: Scaling SAP Business AI Through GenAI Hub

 

This diagram shows a practical way to scale SAP Business AI securely: SAP applications consume AI through a single governed layer (GenAI Hub), while execution can happen either in SAP AI Core (including BYOM) or via approved external model providers. The key architectural decision here is to avoid "point-to-point AI integrations" where every app team separately manages model endpoints, credentials, and logging. Instead, GenAI Hub becomes the orchestration, trust, control, and routing layer‚Äîcentralizing authentication/authorization, selecting the right model for each use case, and ensuring consistent telemetry across the landscape.

What Happens Under the Hood (Data Flow)

  1. A user triggers an AI feature from SAP applications such as S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, Ariba, or SAP Fiori.
  2. The request is sent to GenAI Hub, which acts as the enterprise gateway for GenAI requests. At this point, GenAI Hub applies centralized controls: who is calling, what they are allowed to do, and which model endpoints are permitted. Critically, SAP applications never connect directly to LLM providersall requests flow through GenAI Hub, ensuring no credentials, tokens, or business data bypass the governance layer.
  3. GenAI Hub then routes the request down one of two execution paths:
    1. External approved model providers (e.g., Azure OpenAI, AWS Bedrock, Google Vertex AI, other approved models) when the use case allows external inference and the right provider is configured.
    2. SAP AI Core when you need SAP-managed runtime governance, want to run custom/BYOM models (PyTorch, TensorFlow), or require data to remain entirely within SAP's infrastructure.
  1. For grounding use cases (RAG), the flow can retrieve enterprise context from HANA Cloud Vector Engine, using vector indexing and similarity search to fetch the most relevant snippets. This makes responses more accurate and reduces hallucinations because the model is guided by trusted enterprise context rather than relying on the base model alone.
  2. The response returns through GenAI Hub back to the calling SAP application.

Security, Privacy, and AI Safety ‚Äî Why This Pattern Matters

From a cybersecurity perspective, this design reduces attack surface by centralizing sensitive controls in one place. Authentication and authorization are enforced at the orchestration layer, model access is restricted to approved endpoints, and telemetry is standardized so security teams can monitor usage patterns, spikes, and anomalous behavior. When BYOM is used, SAP AI Core provides a managed container runtime where organizations can apply enterprise controls such as hardened images, secrets isolation, environment separation, and controlled deployment lifecycles. Importantly, SAP AI Launchpad provides the operational governance layer for AI Core (deploy, monitor, scale), helping prevent uncontrolled model changes in production.

From a data privacy and safety standpoint, the architecture supports "minimum necessary data" and better guardrails. Only required context should be sent for inference, and where external providers are used, this pattern naturally supports adding a trust layer (masking/tokenization and input/output filtering) before any data leaves the SAP boundary. SAP maintains strict contractual agreements with all external LLM providers, explicitly prohibiting customer data from being used for model training or retention beyond the inference session. For RAG, the vector store becomes a governed enterprise memory: the most important safety control is to ensure retrieval is authorization-aware, so users only see content they are entitled to access. Combined, these controls help customers adopt GenAI faster without losing control over data handling, residency decisions, auditability, and safety outcomes.

Enforcing Trust Boundaries in SAP Joule‚Äôs AI Execution Flow

 SAP Joule is a generative AI co-pilot natively embedded across SAP's cloud portfolio, including SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, and SAP Concur. Running as a service on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) in a Cloud Foundry environment, Joule leverages SAP's Generative AI Hub on SAP BTP to orchestrate secure interactions with Large Language Models. This architecture enables Joule to deliver contextually aware responses grounded in real business data while maintaining strict enterprise security and data privacy controls.

 

Step

Phase

Description

1

User Utterance

The user enters a natural language prompt (e.g., "Change my address" or "Explain the travel policy") into the Joule interface.

2

Grounding (A, B, C)

Joule enriches the raw prompt by pulling from three sources:



(2A) Scenario Catalogue: Matches the intent to specific business functions (e.g., S/4HANA or SuccessFactors).



(2B) Knowledge Catalogue: Adds relevant SAP help or customer-specific documents via Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG).



(2C) Context: Incorporates the user‚Äôs history, specific role, and current session data.

3

Function Call

If the request requires action or data retrieval from the system, Joule triggers a specific backend function.

4

Data Execution

The function communicates directly with SAP backend systems (like Cloud ERP, HXM, or BTP) via secure APIs.

5

Back-end Reply

The backend returns the requested data or confirmation of the action back to the Joule orchestrator.

6

Enriched Query

Joule bundles the original prompt with all retrieved business data and context, sending a "Grounding-rich" request to the LLM.

7

Grounded Response

The LLM processes the enriched prompt and returns a response that is now factually accurate based on the provided business context.

8

Rendered Answer

Joule performs a final security and privacy check before displaying the natural language answer to the user.

Security by Design in SAP Joule

Security in SAP Joule is not an afterthought. This is foundational to the architecture. Joule is built on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) and inherits SAP‚Äôs enterprise-grade security controls across identity, access management, network protection, and continuous monitoring. This ensures AI-assisted interactions are governed with the same rigor as direct system access.

Authentication and Identity Management

SAP Joule relies on SAP Cloud Identity Services to authenticate users and manage identities consistently across SAP applications.

  • Identity Authentication Service (IAS)‚Ä®Authenticates users and verifies identity before granting access to Joule.
  • Identity Provisioning Service (IPS)‚Ä®Synchronizes users, roles, and attributes from source systems (such as SAP SuccessFactors) to SAP BTP, ensuring Joule reflects the user‚Äôs current authorizations.

This approach ensures Joule operates within the same identity framework as the underlying SAP landscape.

 OAuth 2.0 Authorization and Secure Access

  • Joule is deployed on SAP BTP and uses standard OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code flow for secure access.
  • User requests are routed through an SAP BTP AppRouter
  • XSUAA issues OAuth tokens based on the configured trust with the customer‚Äôs identity provider
  • Authentication follows the SAP BTP subaccount trust configuration

When accessing backend systems, Joule uses principal propagation, meaning it acts on behalf of the authenticated user. As a result, Joule can only perform actions and retrieve data that the user is already authorized to access in the native SAP application.

Role-Based Access Control

Joule does not introduce a separate permission model.

Instead:

  • It inherits role-based access control (RBAC) from the connected SAP applications
  • Authorization checks are enforced before any data access or function execution
  • AI-assisted interactions are consistent with direct application access

If a user cannot view data or execute a transaction in an SAP application, Joule will enforce the same restriction.

Encryption and Transport Security

All communication involving Joule is protected using strong encryption:

  • TLS 1.2 or higher for all data in transit
  • Secure communication with:
  • SAP backend systems (e.g., S/4HANA Cloud, SuccessFactors)
  • SAP Generative AI Hub
  • Approved third-party LLM providers

Data at rest within SAP-managed cloud infrastructure is encrypted, with encryption keys handled through SAP‚Äôs centralized key management services.

Proactive Security and Continuous Governance

SAP applies multiple layers of proactive security controls to Joule:

  • Penetration Testing and Red Teaming‚Ä®Regular security testing to identify and remediate vulnerabilities.
  • Third-Party LLM Risk Management‚Ä®All LLM integrations undergo security, privacy, compliance, and ethical risk assessments before enablement.
  • Continuous Monitoring‚Ä®Real-time monitoring and incident response capabilities across SAP BTP and Joule services.
  • These measures ensure Joule remains resilient against evolving threats while meeting enterprise and regulatory expectations.

SAP Business AI Architecture Comparison

Even though SAP builds the AI architecture, customer, remain the pilot in command for risk acceptance and regulatory compliance. Understanding the "trust boundaries" of SAP Business AI allows customer to have informed conversations with your CISO, legal, and risk teams.

Four Critical Questions Every Leader Should Ask:

  • Data Residency: Where does my enterprise data stay, and where does it move during processing?
  • Execution Layer: Does this AI run inside the core system or on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)?
  • Grounding Method: Is the response purely generated by the model, or is it grounded in my specific business data?
  • Governance: What specific audit controls and security guardrails is SAP applying to this process?

SAP Business AI spans multiple architectural patterns, ranging from deterministic, in-stack machine learning to governed generative AI. Internally, SAP already maps every AI capability to one of these models based on:

  • The nature of the use case
  • Data sensitivity
  • Execution requirements
  • Regulatory and compliance considerations

For example:

  1. Embedded AI scenarios in SAP S/4HANA operate entirely within the digital core, with no data leaving the system boundary.
  2. Side-by-side AI scenarios execute on SAP Business Technology Platform, where SAP applications enforce authentication, authorization, and data minimization before invoking AI services.
  3. Generative AI scenarios that interact with enterprise data are implemented using secure Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), ensuring responses are grounded in authorized business context.
  4. Enterprise-scale copilots and cross-application AI capabilities are governed centrally through SAP GenAI Hub, with SAP AI Core providing controlled execution.
  5. Customers enable these models by activating AI use cases, not by architecting them.

Conclusion

Regardless of the specific architecture, SAP applies a risk-based approach to AI governance assessing each use case and implementing the guardrails needed to protect customer data. entry.title: Accelerating Your Analytics with Delta Table Replication into SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Related Blogs:
  • Unlocking the True Potential of Data in Files with SAP HANA Database SQL on Files in SAP HANA Cloud
  • Exploring New SQL on Files Use Cases with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 04/2024 and QRC 01/2025

The way we innovate with data is constantly evolving. Since SAP HANA Cloud QRC 04/2024, SAP HANA Cloud has supported read-only access to external Delta Sharing with a dedicated deltasharing adapter, as I introduced in my previous blog. This capability has been instrumental in enabling real-time analytics without physically moving data, unlocking efficiency and delivering faster insights. But what if your business cases demand not just seamless access but also replication of critical datasets into SAP HANA Cloud for deeper analysis, faster queries, or advanced integration?

That‚Äôs where Delta table-to-HANA replication comes in. Starting with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 04/2025, I‚Äôm glad to introduce this new capability, which provides more flexibility to replicate your Delta table directly into the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, empowering your analytics with greater speed, reliability, and robust data management.

In a nutshell, the new Delta table-to-HANA replication has the following capabilities and characteristics:

  • Remote subscription-based initial load and Change Data Capture (CDC) for both file adapter and deltasharing adapter.
  • Support for either chunk-based, user-driven initial load or streamlined, one-step initial load.
  • Support for either user-driven CDC or system-scheduled CDC using the replication job scheduler.
  • Offer both column-wise and row-wise sub-table replication while enabling source-side schema changes (adding columns only).
  • In addition to normal load behavior, UPSERT load behavior with three additional metadata columns: type, last-processed time, and Delta table version.
  • Simplified replication with virtual table toggling and Data Replication UI for the deltasharing adapter in addition to the remote subscription-based replication.

As depicted in the diagram above, the following four combinations can be considered based on the business use case:

  • Chunk-based Initial Load ‚Üí User-driven CDC
  • Chunk-based Initial Load ‚Üí Scheduled CDC
  • One-step Initial Load ‚Üí User-driven CDC
  • One-step initial Load ‚Üí Scheduled CDC

While the one-step initial load is more straightforward and intuitive, chunk-based initial load is useful when the data volume during the initial load is large. With chunk-based initial load, users can have more granular control over the process by splitting the data into multiple chunks and loading them separately. This approach makes the initial load more manageable and easier to handle, especially when dealing with a vast volume of data.

Once the initial load is complete, Change Data Capture (CDC) is required to reflect any data changes on the source side. User-driven CDC allows users to replicate data based on a specific version. This can be particularly useful when the exact Delta table version for replication is known, and there is no need to automatically replicate all the latest changes. Alternatively, scheduled CDC can be used if the use case involves automatic replication at specific time intervals. In this scenario, the default time interval is 3,600 seconds (1 hour), but custom values can be configured as needed.

Now, let‚Äôs dive deeper into the details with some examples. For this, I will use the combination of chunk-based initial load and scheduled CDC with Delta Sharing as the remote source, which is expected to be the most common scenario. However, as explained, other combinations or setups with direct object storage access can also be easily configured by following the linked documentation.

 

Chunk-based Initial Load

As the focus of this blog is Delta table-to-HANA replication, let‚Äôs assume that the remote source to Delta Sharing has already been created and data is accessible via a virtual table. If you‚Äôre not familiar with this, please refer to my previous blogs.

In this example, a virtual table, V_ORDERS, is created by pointing to the remote shared table within Delta Sharing, and it contains 1,500,000 records.

The first step is to create an empty table as the replication target, using the virtual table schema for its definition.

-- create a target table using the virtual table schema for the definition
CREATE TABLE DEMO.R_ORDERS LIKE DEMO.V_ORDERS;

With this, a remote subscription can now be created as shown below.

-- create a remote subscription
CREATE REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION ON DEMO.V_ORDERS TARGET TABLE DEMO.R_ORDERS;

Here, if needed, as briefly mentioned, column-wise or row-wise sub-table replication can be configured by using a subquery with the CREATE REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION ... ON ... AS <subquery> TARGET TABLE ...;. Additionally, enabling source-side schema changes (adding columns only) or defining load behaviors can also be done together.

Once a remote subscription is created, we now have two options: the chunk-based initial load and the one-step initial load. In this example, I will use the chunk-based initial load.

-- prepare the initial load by defining the chunk size
ALTER REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION INITIAL LOAD PREPARE CHUNK SIZE 10;

-- retrieve the chunk information
SELECT * FROM M_REMOTE_SUBSCRIPTION_INITIAL_LOADS;

In this example, I set the chunk size to 10, which is 10 MiB. However, it is also possible not to define the chunk size here, as in the statement ALTER REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION INITIAL LOAD PREPARE;. If the chunk size is not specified, the default size of 100 MiB will be used.

If I check the chunk information in the M_REMOTE_SUBSCRIPTION_INITIAL_LOADS monitoring view, the result is as follows.

As you can see, three chunks with CHUNK_IDs 1, 2, and 3 are defined, and each chunk contains approximately 430,000 to 537,000 records, respectively. The EXECUTION_STATUS column indicates whether a chunk has been loaded or not. Since I haven‚Äôt loaded any of them yet, all of them show as PREPARED.

Now, let me load chunks 1 and 2 first.

-- load chunks 1 and 2
ALTER REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION INITIAL LOAD EXECUTE CHUNK 1, 2;

-- retrieve the chunk information
SELECT * FROM M_REMOTE_SUBSCRIPTION_INITIAL_LOADS;

Since only chunks 1 and 2 are loaded, the EXECUTION_STATUS in the monitoring view now shows LOADED for those two chunks, as shown below.

In this way, each chunk can be loaded as desired, and its status can be monitored. With that, let me load the last chunk and finalize the initial load.

-- load the chunk 3
ALTER REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION INITIAL LOAD EXECUTE CHUNK 3;

-- finalize the initial load
ALTER REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION INITIAL LOAD FINALIZE;

All chunks must be marked as LOADED in EXECUTION_STATUS to finalize the initial load. FINALIZE will also delete all corresponding rows in the M_REMOTE_SUBSCRIPTION_INITIAL_LOADS monitoring view. Now, I can see that all data has been loaded into the R_ORDERS table.

Please refer to the links below for further details on the initial load.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database SQL on Files Guide: Configuring Delta Table Replication
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database SQL on Files Guide: Performing an Initial Load

 

Scheduled CDC

Once the initial load is finalized, CDC can be achieved in two ways: user-driven CDC or scheduled CDC. In this example, I will use the scheduled CDC.

-- scheduled CDC with a 30-minute interval (1,800 seconds)
ALTER REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION DISTRIBUTE INTERVAL 1800;

-- retrieve the replication jobs
SELECT * FROM M_REMOTE_REPLICATION_JOBS;

If the interval is not specified, the default time interval of 3,600 seconds (1 hour) will be used. In this example, completed and planned replication jobs can be retrieved via the M_REMOTE_REPLICATION_JOBS monitoring view.

As shown above, the first CDC job was planned for 05:35:19 and completed successfully. The next job is planned for 06:05:19, which is 30 minutes later, as expected. One important note is that, to execute the DISTRIBUTE, the enableChangeDataFeed property must be set on the source Delta table.

Please refer to the links below for further details on the CDC.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database SQL on Files Guide: Performing System-scheduled CDC Replication
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database SQL on Files Guide: Performing User-driven CDC Replication

 

Deactivate and Drop Remote Subscription

If needed, the configured remote subscription can be deactivated and dropped using the statements below.

-- deactivate the remote subscription
ALTER REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION RESET;

-- drop the remote subscription 
DROP REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION;

Deactivating the remote subscription will cancel all planned replication jobs from the scheduled CDC. However, since the remote subscription itself remains active, you can start again from the initial load step. Please note that the replica table, R_ORDERS in this example, will still contain replicated data. Therefore, truncating the replica table is required to start over.

Dropping the remote subscription will delete all entries, including the monitoring views. However, the replica table, R_ORDERS in this example, will remain with the replicated data and can be used as a normal table.

Please refer to the links below for further details on the deactivation and drop.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database SQL on Files Guide: Configuring Delta Table Replication

 

Other Interfaces

The remote subscription-based initial load and CDC combination mentioned above is the primary interface used for Delta table-to-HANA replication. However, there are a couple of other interfaces with simplified steps.

The first option involves toggling between federation and replication for the virtual table. Toggling has been supported previously, but only with snapshot replication. Starting with QRC 04/2025, toggling now supports real-time replication as well, as shown below.

-- add a system-owned replica to a virtual table with a 30-minute interval
ALTER VIRTUAL TABLE V_ORDERS ADD SHARED REPLICA REFRESH INTERVAL 1800;

-- delete a replica
ALTER VIRTUAL TABLE V_ORDERS DROP REPLICA;

In this approach, any queries on the virtual table will retrieve data from the replica instead of fetching data on-the-fly from the remote table. Since this is a simplified one-step process designed to offer better performance while maintaining the target object as a virtual table, it does not support granular controls such as chunk-based initial load or sub-table replication. The above example illustrates a system-owned replica, but a user-owned replica is also supported. Here, as with the remote subscription-based approach, if REFRESH INTERVAL is not specified, the default time interval of 3,600 seconds (1 hour) will be used.

Please refer to the links below for further details on the toggling.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database SQL on Files Guide: Toggling Between Virtual Tables and Replica Tables

Another interface involves using the SAP HANA Cloud Central UI. In SAP HANA Cloud Central, Data Replication has been utilized for hybrid scenarios, such as replicating data from SAP HANA Platform 2.0 to SAP HANA Cloud. Starting with QRC 04/2025, Data Replication now also supports replicating data from Delta Sharing to SAP HANA Cloud.

In this UI, either an existing remote source for Delta Sharing can be used or a new remote source can be created while configuring replication.

Unlike other interfaces, it only supports the Delta Sharing remote source, which is based on the deltasharing adapter.

As shown above, once the data objects to be replicated are selected, the replication schedule can be set to either 'Real Time', which uses scheduled CDC, or 'None', which performs only a one-time initial load. For 'Real Time', as explained above, the enableChangeDataFeed property must be set on the source Delta table.

Once confirmed, the replication status can now be monitored. For example, 'Completed', which means the one-time initial load is finished, or 'Loading...', which indicates that scheduled CDC is being activated.

Similar to toggling, as it is a simplified approach, it does not support granular controls such as chunk-based initial load, sub-table replication, or setting time intervals. However, like existing SAP HANA Platform 2.0-to-SAP HANA Cloud hybrid scenarios, it provides a way to configure the replication schedule, storage type, and a consolidated view of all replication tasks. Please refer to the links below for further details on using the SAP HANA Cloud Central UI.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Data Replication in SAP HANA Cloud Central

 

Conclusion

To wrap things up, the Delta table replication capability introduced with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 04/2025 represents a transformative step forward in data integration and analytics. This advanced functionality provides businesses with the flexibility to address diverse use cases, enabling deeper insights and streamlined data management. Whether the focus is on real-time updates or managing large-scale initial data loads, these features deliver tailored solutions designed to optimize performance and efficiency. With SAP HANA Cloud at the forefront of innovation, the possibilities for unlocking the true power of your data are boundless. Be sure to explore these exciting capabilities to elevate your enterprise to the next level.
